_prev_prog_3.Description: The SCR process that utilizes ammonia at the Whiting Clean Energy Cogeneration facility in Whiting, IN is a newly constructed cogeneration facility.  Primary Energy (PE) is implementing a prevention program based on the PSM program implemented at the facility.  As part of the implementation, PE has completed a thorough pre-startup safety review for the new ammonia system, as well as a checklist health and safety review.  In addition, PE is planning to conduct employee training on the hazards of handling ammonia on an ongoing basis, as the number of employees is expected to increase in the coming months.  PE is in the process of developing the operating procedures for the ammonia system, incorporating safe work practices for conducting hot work, lockout/tagout, and confined space operations at the facility.  PE is also developing a mechanical integrity program for the ammonia system equipment to ensure the equipment is maintained in optimum working condition; PE uses equipment manufacturers? recommended maintenance tasks and schedules, as well as past operating experience to complete the mechanical integrity program. PE has developed a contractor safety program for contractors hired to work on the ammonia system.  Finally, the PSM written program incorporates the facility's emergency response plan and places special emphasis on handling accidental releases of ammonia and coordination of emergency response with local fire departments, the neighboring B.P. Amoco HAZMAT team and other emergency response organizations.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INTRODUCTION
The Whiting Clean Energy Cogeneration facility in Whiting, Indiana owned and operated by Primary Energy are in the process of installing a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) unit which will utilize ammonia for reduction of NOx emissions. The ammonia for use in the SCR process will be stored in a 6,000-gallon storage tank located at the facility. At full capacity, the tank can store 29,000 pounds of ammonia. Since the facility will be storing more than 10,000 lbs of anhydrous ammonia, the SCR ammonia process is subject to United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations codified in 40CFR Part 68.

Ammonia is an easily liquefiable colorless gas with a sharp, intensely irritating odor. It is listed by the USEPA as a regulated toxic substance for release prevention.

RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY
Pursuant to the Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations (40 CFR Part 68) and the Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119), Primary Energy has developed a comprehensive PSM written program to protect employees and the surrounding community from exposure to ammonia.  The facility completed detailed Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) through checklist analyses and a complete Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) for ammonia using the industry standard What-If?/Checklist Analysis developed through the International Institute for Ammonia Refrigeration. The PHA was completed in April 2001 using technical and operations staff from the facility as well as experienced facilitators from URS Corporation, an outside consulting firm.

Primary Energy is committed to the safe operation of SCR ammonia system at the Whiting facility. Primary Energy?s implementation of the PSM program includes employee education in the hazards of ammonia and measures that can be used to reduce employee and community exposure to accidental releases of ammonia. The plan includes preventive maintenance programs (mechanical inte

grity) for the ammonia system that incorporates inspections of the system in accordance with recognized standards of equipment inspection within the ammonia industry, as well as tests of system components in accordance with component manufacturers? recommendations. 

The PSM plan includes programs for pre-startup safety reviews and management of changes (MOC) to the ammonia system. The program also includes specific requirements for safe work practices (such as safe approaches to welding and similar hot work) and safety requirements for contractors who may be hired to work on the systems. The PSM program also includes a program for the evaluation of contractors. 

The PSM written program incorporates the facility?s comprehensive emergency response plan in concert with the adjoining B. P. Amoco Whiting Refinery facility and place special emphasis on handling accidental releases of ammonia and coordination of emergency response with local fire departments and other emergency response organizations such as the Lake County LEPC.

Since the system has not been formally commissioned, Primary Energy has not completed a compliance audit of the PSM program.  A compliance audit of the newly implemented PSM program will be completed in the first quarter of 2002. 

As part of the RMP requirements, Primary Energy undertook a review of the potential offsite consequences of the accidental releases from the largest vessel in the system ? the 6,000-gallon ammonia storage tank.  Although such a release is highly unlikely, the regulation requires this review. 

WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO
As required by USEPA regulations, the worst-case release scenario was assumed to be the complete loss of contents of the 6,000-gallon storage tank containing 29,000 lbs of anhydrous ammonia.  In this analysis no passive mitigation measures were assumed. The USEPA guidance for defining a worst-case release scenario for unmitigated release of gas is to estimate the release rate over a 10-minute period

of the largest quantity resulting from a pipe or vessel failure.  Thus, the ammonia emission rate from the worst-case release scenario used was the loss of 29,000 lbs of ammonia averaged over a 10-minute period, i.e., 2,900 lbs/min.

USEPA?s public-domain RMP*Comp model was used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/lit (or 200 ppm). The model predicted a downwind distance of 2 miles as the distance to the toxic endpoint due to the specified worst-case release. Based on LandView III output, the total population within the potential exposure area is 6,000 with the following public receptors being potentially impacted ? schools, residences, recreation areas and industrial areas. It should be noted that the potential offsite impact due to a release is greatly minimized on account of the location of the facility which is bounded by Lake Michigan on the north and east. Since almost 40 percent of the area within the circle of influence defined by the distance to the toxic endpoint as the radius is over Lake Michigan with the majority of the remaining area of influence bounded by an industrial estate, potential offsite impacts are greatly reduced.

Once the facility is commissioned, Primary Energy employees will thoroughly inspect the ammonia system per the recommendations of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and the provisions of the written Process Safety Management (PSM). This will greatly minimize the chance that the tank will fully discharge its contents in a release and minimizes the potential for an offsite impact.

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO
For the Whiting facility, the alternative release scenario was assumed to be the structural failure of a 2-inch pipe filled with ammonia at 25 psig beyond the confines of the concrete dike. Assumed active mitigation (e.g., use of emergency shutdown systems etc.) starts within a reasonable time after the accidental release begins. For this analysis, the total release duration is assumed to be the time peri

od from the beginning of the release event until the release is totally contained. The total release duration was assumed to be 15 minutes. In this analysis, no passive mitigation measures were assumed.  Thus, the ammonia emission rate from the alternative release scenario is given as the loss of 17,550 lbs of ammonia averaged over a 15-minute period, i.e., 1,170 lbs/min.

USEPA?s public-domain RMP*Comp model was used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/lit (or 200 ppm). The model predicted a downwind distance of 0.2 miles as the distance to the toxic endpoint due to the specified alternative release. Based on LandView III output, the total population within the potential exposure area is 34 with the only public receptors being potentially impacted being industrial areas. It should be noted that the potential offsite impact due to a release is greatly minimized on account of the location of the facility which is bounded by Lake Michigan on the north and east.

Once the facility is commissioned, Primary Energy employees will thoroughly inspect the ammonia system per the recommendations of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and the provisions of the written Process Safety Management (PSM). This will greatly minimize the chance that there will be any discharge of tank contents in a release and minimizes the potential for an offsite impact.

RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
As indicated earlier, Primary Energy has proactively implemented an OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program (codified in 29CFR Part 1910.119) for the SCR ammonia process.  The scope of the PSM program encompasses various facets of release prevention; e.g., it engenders employee participation, increases employee awareness about the hazards of handling ammonia, establishes safe standard operating procedures and enhances access to process safety information. In April 2001, Primary Energy performed a HAZOP Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) on the SCR ammonia system with the help of outs

ide consultants in order to review operating procedures, equipment maintenance schedules, operational safeguards and identify action items to render the process safer. Following the PHA, the Whiting facility developed a written PSM program with the help of outside consultants. The written PSM program provides the procedural backbone for safe operability functions (i.e., continual review of safe operating procedures, review of mechanical integrity of equipment, improved maintenance schedules, increased training, better access to process safety information and hazard awareness for both employees and onsite contractors, and effective emergency response planning), and allows Primary Energy to maintain, review and evaluate the program on a periodic basis.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The SCR ammonia process will be operational in the third quarter of 2001. Thus, there is no operational history during which the facility has experienced a release of ammonia involving consequences that affected residents or the environment. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The PSM written program incorporates the facility?s comprehensive emergency response plan in concert with the adjoining B. P. Amoco Whiting Refinery facility and place special emphasis on handling accidental releases of ammonia and coordination of emergency response with local fire departments and other emergency response organizations such as the Lake County LEPC. The response plan details the emergency response structure and includes personnel responsibilities and procedures within that structure.  In addition, the plan includes procedures for notification of local agencies in the event of an incident, facility evacuation, and decontamination  Finally, the plan discusses emergency preparedness and planning, including facility plans for conducting emergency response team training and drills.

The Primary Energy management is committed to supporting the emergency response (ER) organization and its prescribed functions. ER team

members are drawn from the existing employee pool and the organizational concept fosters pride and emphasizes concerns for safe operation of the plant. The well defined ER organization at the facility operating in conjunction with the B. P. Amoco Whiting Refinery HAZMAT team, the local Fire Department and the Lake County LEPC alleviate safety concerns about handling ammonia at the plant.
